pos.etymology: [F. zafre, safre; cf. Sp. zafra, safra, It. saffera, G. zaffer; all probably of Arabic origin.  Cf. Zaphara.]

definitions.text: Z, the twenty-sixth and last letter of the English alphabet, is a vocal consonant. It is taken from the Latin letter Z, which came from the Greek alphabet, this having it from a Semitic source. The ultimate origin is probably Egyptian. Etymologically, it is most closely related to s, y, and j; as in glass, glaze; E. yoke, Gr. yugum; E. zealous, jealous.  See Guide to Pronunciation, 1913 Webster]

pos.etymology: [F. zafre, safre; cf. Sp. zafra, safra, It. saffera, G. zaffer; all probably of Arabic origin.  Cf. Zaphara.]

definitions.text: An old solfeggio name for B flat; the seventh harmonic, as heard in the or aeolian string; -- so called by Tartini. It was long considered a false, but is the true note of the chord of the flat seventh.

pos.etymology: [F. zafre, safre; cf. Sp. zafra, safra, It. saffera, G. zaffer; all probably of Arabic origin.  Cf. Zaphara.]

definitions.text: See Sabianism.

pos.etymology: [F. zafre, safre; cf. Sp. zafra, safra, It. saffera, G. zaffer; all probably of Arabic origin.  Cf. Zaphara.]

definitions.text: See Sabian.

pos.etymology: [F. zafre, safre; cf. Sp. zafra, safra, It. saffera, G. zaffer; all probably of Arabic origin.  Cf. Zaphara.]

definitions.text: See Zocco.

pos.etymology: [F. zafre, safre; cf. Sp. zafra, safra, It. saffera, G. zaffer; all probably of Arabic origin.  Cf. Zaphara.]

definitions.text: An oil pressed by the Arabs from the fruit of a small thorny tree (Balanites Aegyptiaca), and sold to piligrims for a healing ointment.

pos.etymology: [F. zafre, safre; cf. Sp. zafra, safra, It. saffera, G. zaffer; all probably of Arabic origin.  Cf. Zaphara.]

definitions.text: Same as Z.

pos.etymology: [Russ. zastruga furrow made on the shore by water.]

definitions.text: A European bream (Abramis vimba).

pos.etymology: [F. zafre, safre; cf. Sp. zafra, safra, It. saffera, G. zaffer; all probably of Arabic origin.  Cf. Zaphara.]

definitions.text: A pigment obtained, usually by roasting cobalt glance with sand or quartz, as a dark earthy powder. It consists of crude cobalt oxide, or of an impure cobalt arseniate. It is used in porcelain painting, and in enameling pottery, to produce a blue color, and is often confounded with smalt, from which, however, it is distinct, as it contains no potash. The name is often loosely applied to mixtures of zaffer proper with silica, or oxides of iron, manganese, etc.
A Turkish chief who supports a mounted militia bearing the same name.
A district from which a Zaim draws his revenue.
A horse of a dark color, neither gray nor white, and having no spots.
Of or pertaining to a tribe (Zalambdodonta) of Insectivora in which the molar teeth have but one V-shaped ridge.
One of the Zalambdodonta. The tenrec, solenodon, and golden moles are examples.
the battle in 202 BC in which Scipio decisively defeated Hannibal at the end of the second Punic War.
A large ornamental tropical American tree (Albizia saman) with bipinnate leaves and globose clusters of flowers with crimson stamens and sweet-pulp seed pods eaten by cattle.

An immense leguminous tree (Pithecolobium Saman) of Venezuela. Its branches form a hemispherical mass, often one hundred and eighty feet across. The sweet pulpy pods are used commonly for feeding cattle. Also called rain tree.
a native or inhabitant of Zambia.
of or pertaining to Zambia; as, Zambian cities.
Of or pertaining to the inhabitants of Zambia; as, the Zambian President.
The child of a mulatto and a negro; also, the child of an Indian and a negro; colloquially or humorously, a negro; a sambo.

pos.etymology: [L. zamia a kind of fir cone, from Gr.  (Bot.) A genus of cycadaceous plants, having the appearance of low palms, but with exogenous wood.  See Coontie, and Illust. of Strobile.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A genus of cycadaceous plants, having the appearance of low palms, but with exogenous wood.  See Coontie, and Illust. of Strobile.

pos.etymology: [Hind. zem, zam, a landholder, Per. zam; zam land d holding.]

definitions.text: A landowner; also, a collector of land revenue; now, usually, a kind of feudatory recognized as an actual proprietor so long as he pays to the government a certain fixed revenue.
The jurisdiction of a zamindar; the land possessed by a zamindar.
A fossil cycad of the genus Zamia.

A West African buffalo (Bubalus brachyceros) having short horns depressed at the base, and large ears fringed internally with three rows of long hairs. It is destitute of a dewlap. Called also short-horned buffalo, and bush cow.
A sort of bagpipe formerly in use among Italian peasants. It is now almost obsolete.
A European pike perch (Stizostedion lucioperca) allied to the wall-eye; -- called also sandari, sander, sannat, schill, and zant.

pos.etymology: [Cf. D. zand sand.  See Sand, and Mole the animal.]

definitions.text: The sand mole.

pos.etymology: [It. zanni a buffoon, merry-andrew, orig. same as Giovanni John, i. e., merry John, L. Ioannes, Gr. Y, prop., the Lord graciously gave: cf. F. zani, fr. the Italian.  Cf. Jenneting.]

definitions.text: See Zantewood.

pos.etymology: [It. zanni a buffoon, merry-andrew, orig. same as Giovanni John, i. e., merry John, L. Ioannes, Gr. Y, prop., the Lord graciously gave: cf. F. zani, fr. the Italian.  Cf. Jenneting.]

definitions.text: A kind of seedless grape or raisin; -- so called from Zante, one of the Ionian Islands.

pos.etymology: [It. zanni a buffoon, merry-andrew, orig. same as Giovanni John, i. e., merry John, L. Ioannes, Gr. Y, prop., the Lord graciously gave: cf. F. zani, fr. the Italian.  Cf. Jenneting.]

definitions.text: A yellow dyewood; fustet; -- called also zante, and zante fustic.  See Fustet, and the Note under Fustic.

pos.etymology: [It. zanni a buffoon, merry-andrew, orig. same as Giovanni John, i. e., merry John, L. Ioannes, Gr. Y, prop., the Lord graciously gave: cf. F. zani, fr. the Italian.  Cf. Jenneting.]

definitions.text: A native or inhabitant of Zante, one of the Ionian Islands.

pos.etymology: [It. zanni a buffoon, merry-andrew, orig. same as Giovanni John, i. e., merry John, L. Ioannes, Gr. Y, prop., the Lord graciously gave: cf. F. zani, fr. the Italian.  Cf. Jenneting.]

definitions.text: Comical in a clownish or buffoonish manner; whimsically comical.

pos.etymology: [It. zanni a buffoon, merry-andrew, orig. same as Giovanni John, i. e., merry John, L. Ioannes, Gr. Y, prop., the Lord graciously gave: cf. F. zani, fr. the Italian.  Cf. Jenneting.]

definitions.text: A merry-andrew; a buffoon.
examples: Then write that I may follow, and so bezany.
Preacher at once, and zany of thy age.

definitions.text: To mimic.
examples: Your part is acted; give me leave at distancezany it.

definitions.text: State or character of a zany; buffoonery.
to shoot, destroy, or inactivate; my TV set was zapped by lightning.
to bomb with an atomic bomb.
to cook or heat in a microwave oven.
to subject to radiation, a laser beam, a strong electric current, or other potentially destructive treatment.
to skip over (e. g. a commercial or dull interval in a television program) by using the fast-forward button on a VCR remove control.
to add interest, color, or attractiveness to; to liven; -- usually used with up.
See Army organization, above.
A cured olive which has spoiled or is on the verge of decomposition; loosely, an olive defective because of bruises, wormholes, or the like.
Zaffer.
An extinct genus of cyathophylloid corals common in the Paleozoic formations. It is cup-shaped with numerous septa, and with a deep pit in one side of the cup.
See Sapodilla.
A Turkish policeman.
The Persian name for Zoroaster.
Of or pertaining to Zarathustra, or Zoroaster; Zoroastrian.
See Zoroastrianism.
A hydrous carbonate of nickel occurring as an emerald-green incrustation on chromite; -- called also emerald nickel.
An improvised stockade; especially, one made of thorn bushes, etc.
examples: zareba like the troops after Osman Digma. R. Jefferies.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A metallic cuplike stand used for holding a finjan.

pos.etymology: [F., fr. Ar. az-zern, fr. Gr. Arsenic.]

definitions.text: Native sulphide of arsenic, including sandarach, or realgar, and orpiment.

pos.etymology: [Russ. zastruga furrow made on the shore by water.]

definitions.text: Grooves or furrows formed in snow by the action of the wind, and running parallel with the direction of the wind. This formation results from the erosion of transverse waves previously formed.

pos.etymology: [NL., named for M. Zauschner, a Bohemian botanist.]

definitions.text: A species of macaque (Macacus pileatus) native of India and Ceylon. It has a crown of long erect hair, and tuft of radiating hairs on the back of the head. Called also capped macaque.

pos.etymology: [NL., named for M. Zauschner, a Bohemian botanist.]

definitions.text: A genus of flowering plants.  Zauschneria Californica is a suffrutescent perennial, with showy red flowers much resembling those of the garden fuchsia.

pos.etymology: [L., a kind of grain, fr. Gr. ze`a, zeia`; cf. Skr. yava barley.]

definitions.text: A tool for trimming and puncturing roofing slates.

pos.etymology: [L., a kind of grain, fr. Gr. ze`a, zeia`; cf. Skr. yava barley.]

definitions.text: A public shed, or portico, for travelers, worshipers, etc.

pos.etymology: [L., a kind of grain, fr. Gr. ze`a, zeia`; cf. Skr. yava barley.]

definitions.text: A genus of large grasses of which the Indian corn (Zea Mays) is the only species known. Its origin is not yet ascertained.  See Maize.

pos.etymology: [F. z; cf. Pg. & It. zelo, Sp. zelo, celo; from L. zelus, Gr. Yeast, Jealous.]

definitions.text: Passionate ardor in the pursuit of anything; eagerness in favor of a person or cause; ardent and active interest; engagedness; enthusiasm; fervor.
examples: I bear them record that they have a zeal of God, but not according to knowledge.
A zeal for liberty is sometimes an eagerness to subvert with little care what shall be established.

definitions.text: A zealot.
To be zealous.
One who is zealous; a zealot; an enthusiast.
examples: To certain zealants, all speech of pacification is odious.

definitions.text: Full of zeal; characterized by zeal.
Full of zeal.
Wanting zeal.

One who is zealous; one who engages warmly in any cause, and pursues his object with earnestness and ardor; especially, one who is overzealous, or carried away by his zeal; one absorbed in devotion to anything; an enthusiast; a fanatical partisan.
examples: Zealots for the one [tradition] were in hostile array against zealots for the other.
In Ayrshire, Clydesdale, Nithisdale, Annandale, every parish was visited by these turbulent zealots.

definitions.text: Like, or suitable to, a zealot; ardently zealous.
The character or conduct of a zealot; zealotry.
A zealot.
The character and behavior of a zealot; excess of zeal; fanatical devotion to a cause.
examples: Enthusiasm, visionariness, seems the tendency of the German; zeal, zealotry, of the English; fanaticism, of the French.

definitions.text: Filled with, or characterized by, zeal; warmly engaged, or ardent, in behalf of an object.
examples: He may be zealous in the salvation of souls.

definitions.text: Filled with religious zeal.

pos.etymology: [Pg. zebra; cf. Sp. cebra; probably from a native African name.]

definitions.text: See Xebec.

pos.etymology: [Pg. zebra; cf. Sp. cebra; probably from a native African name.]

definitions.text: Any member of three species of African wild horses remarkable for having the body white or yellowish white, and conspicuously marked with dark brown or brackish bands.

pos.cs: Zebra caterpillar, the larva of an American noctuid moth (Mamestra picta). It is light yellow, with a broad black stripe on the back and one on each side; the lateral stripes are crossed with withe lines. It feeds on cabbages, beets, clover, and other cultivated plants. -- Zebra opossum, the zebra wolf.  See under Wolf. -- Zebra parrakeet, an Australian grass parrakeet, often kept as a cage bird. Its upper parts are mostly pale greenish yellow, transversely barred with brownish black crescents; the under parts, rump, and upper tail coverts, are bright green; two central tail feathers and the cheek patches are blue. Called also canary parrot, scallop parrot, shell parrot, and undulated parrot. -- Zebra poison (Bot.), a poisonous tree (Euphorbia arborea) of the Spurge family, found in South Africa. Its milky juice is so poisonous that zebras have been killed by drinking water in which its branches had been placed, and it is also used as an arrow poison. J. Smith (Dict. Econ. Plants). -- Zebra shark. Same as Tiger shark, under Tiger. -- Zebra spider, a hunting spider. -- Zebra swallowtail, a very large North American swallow-tailed butterfly (Iphiclides ajax), in which the wings are yellow, barred with black; -- called also ajax. -- Zebra wolf. See under Wolf.

definitions.text: A lizard having a long tail with black bands (Callisaurus draconoides), which lives in the deserts of the southwestern U. S. and Mexico; called also gridiron-tailed lizard.
A kind of cabinet wood having beautiful black, brown, and whitish stripes, the timber of a tropical American tree (Connarus Guianensis).
Pertaining to, or resembling, the zebra.
A cross between a male horse and a female zebra.
A cross between a male zebra and a female horse.

A bovine mammal (Ros Indicus) extensively domesticated in India, China, the East Indies, and East Africa. It usually has short horns, large pendulous ears, slender legs, a large dewlap, and a large, prominent hump over the shoulders; but these characters vary in different domestic breeds, which range in size from that of the common ox to that of a large mastiff.

pos.etymology: [Gr., fr. zeche a mine + stein a stone.]

definitions.text: A large noxious fly of Abyssinia, which like the tsetse fly, is destructive to cattle.

pos.etymology: [Gr., fr. zeche a mine + stein a stone.]

definitions.text: See Sequin.

pos.etymology: [Gr., fr. zeche a mine + stein a stone.]

definitions.text: The upper division of the Permian (Dyas) of Europe. The prevailing rock is a magnesian limestone.

pos.etymology: [F., probably through It. zeta, fr. L. zeta.  See Zeta.]

definitions.text: The letter Z; -- called also zee, and formerly izzard.

pos.etymology: [F. z, LL. zedoaria; cf. It. zedoaria, zettovario, Pg. zedoaria, Sp. zedoaria, cedoaria; all fr. Ar. & Per. zedw.]

definitions.text: A medicinal substance obtained in the East Indies, having a fragrant smell, and a warm, bitter, aromatic taste. It is used in medicine as a stimulant.
A hippopotamus.

The widening and duplication, triplication, etc., of spectral lines when the radiations emanate in a strong magnetic field, first observed in 1896 by P. Zeeman, a Dutch physicist, and regarded as an important confirmation of the electromagnetic theory of light.
An Austrian silver coin equal to ten kreutzers, or about five cents.
A nitrogenous substance of the nature of gluten, obtained from the seeds of Indian corn (Zea) as a soft, yellowish, amorphous substance.

pos.etymology: [G.; zeit time + geist spirit. See Tide, n.; Ghost, n.]

definitions.text: The spirit of the time; the general intellectual and moral state or temper characteristic of any period of time.
Same as Zamindar.
Same as Zamindary.

The blind mole rat (Spalax typhlus), native of Eastern Europe and Asia. Its eyes and ears are rudimentary, and its fur is soft and brownish, more or less tinged with gray. It constructs extensive burrows.

In Russia, an elective local district and provincial administrative assembly. Originally it was composed of representatives elected by the peasantry, the householders of the towns, and the landed proprietors. In the reign of Alexander III. the power of the noble landowners was increased, the peasants allowed only to elect candidates from whom the governor of the province nominated the deputy, and all acts of the zemstvo subjected to the approval of the governor. Theoretically the zemstvo has large powers relating to taxation, education, public health, etc., but practically these powers are in most cases limited to the adjustment of the state taxation.

pos.etymology: [Hind. zen, zan, fr. Per. zan, fr. zan woman; akin to E. queen.]

definitions.text: The part of a dwelling appropriated to women.
Properly, the translation and exposition in the Huzv1913 Webster]

pos.etymology: [Properly, the Avesta, or sacred text, and its zend, or interpretation, in a more modern and intelligible language. W. D. Whitney.]

definitions.text: The sacred writings of the ancient Persian religion, attributed to Zoroaster, but chiefly of a later date.
An atheist or unbeliever; -- name given in the East to those charged with disbelief of any revealed religion, or accused of magical heresies.

pos.etymology: [OE. senyth, OF. cenith, F. z, Sp. zenit, cenit, abbrev. fr. Ar. samt-urras way of the head, vertical place; samt way, path + al the + ras head.  Cf. Azimuth.]

definitions.text: A South African burrowing mammal (Suricata tetradactyla), allied to the civets. It is grayish brown, with yellowish transverse stripes on the back. Called also suricat.

pos.etymology: [OE. senyth, OF. cenith, F. z, Sp. zenit, cenit, abbrev. fr. Ar. samt-urras way of the head, vertical place; samt way, path + al the + ras head.  Cf. Azimuth.]

definitions.text: See Zenick.

pos.etymology: [OE. senyth, OF. cenith, F. z, Sp. zenit, cenit, abbrev. fr. Ar. samt-urras way of the head, vertical place; samt way, path + al the + ras head.  Cf. Azimuth.]

definitions.text: That point in the visible celestial hemisphere which is vertical to the spectator; the point of the heavens directly overhead; -- opposed to nadir.
examples: From mornzenith, like a falling star.

definitions.text: hence, figuratively, the point of culmination; the greatest height; the height of success or prosperity.
examples: I find my zenith doth depend upon Shak.1913 Webster]
This dead of midnight is the noon of thought,zenith with the stars.
It was during those civil troubles . . . this aspiring family reached the zenith.

pos.cs: Zenith distance. (Astron.) See under Distance. -- Zenith sector. (Astron.) See Sector, 3. -- Zenith telescope (Geodesy), a telescope specially designed for determining the latitude by means of any two stars which pass the meridian about the same time, and at nearly equal distances from the zenith, but on opposite sides of it. It turns both on a vertical and a horizontal axis, is provided with a graduated vertical semicircle, and a level for setting it to a given zenith distance, and with a micrometer for measuring the difference of the zenith distances of the two stars.

definitions.text: Of or pertaining to the zenith.

A term now used to designate any one of a family of minerals, hydrous silicates of alumina, with lime, soda, potash, or rarely baryta. Here are included natrolite, stilbite, analcime, chabazite, thomsonite, heulandite, and others. These species occur of secondary origin in the cavities of amygdaloid, basalt, and lava, also, less frequently, in granite and gneiss. So called because many of these species intumesce before the blowpipe.
Of or pertaining to a zeolite; consisting of, or resembling, a zeolite.
Having the form of a zeolite.
The west wind; poetically, any soft, gentle breeze.
examples: As gentlezephyrs blowing below the violet.

pos.cs: Zephyr cloth, a thin kind of cassimere made in Belgium; also, a waterproof fabric of wool. -- Zephyr shawl, a kind of thin, light, embroidered shawl made of worsted and cotton. -- Zephyr yarn, or Zephyr worsted, a fine, soft kind of yarn or worsted, -- used for knitting and embroidery.

definitions.text: The west wind, or zephyr; -- usually personified, and made the most mild and gentle of all the sylvan deities.
examples: Mild as when Zephyrus on Flora breathes.

definitions.text: A dirigible balloon of the rigid type, consisting of a cylindrical trussed and covered frame supported by internal gas cells, and provided with means of propulsion and  control. It was first successfully used by Ferdinand Count von Zeppelin.
See Sequin.
The fennec.

pos.etymology: [F. z, from Ar. , , empty, a cipher.  Cf. Cipher.]

definitions.text: Same as Zareba.

pos.etymology: [F. z, from Ar. , , empty, a cipher.  Cf. Cipher.]

definitions.text: A cipher; nothing; naught.
The point from which the graduation of a scale, as of a thermometer, commences.
Fig.: The lowest point; the point of exhaustion; as, his patience had nearly reached zero.

pos.cs: Absolute zero. See under Absolute. -- Zero method (Physics), a method of comparing, or measuring, forces, electric currents, etc., by so opposing them that the pointer of an indicating apparatus, or the needle of a galvanometer, remains at, or is brought to, zero, as contrasted with methods in which the deflection is observed directly; -- called also null method. -- Zero point, the point indicating zero, or the commencement of a scale or reckoning.

pos.etymology: [F. zeste, probably fr. L. schistos split, cleft, divided, Gr. Schism.]

definitions.text: A piece of orange or lemon peel, or the aromatic oil which may be squeezed from such peel, used to give flavor to liquor, etc.
Hence, something that gives or enhances a pleasant taste, or the taste itself; an appetizer; also, keen enjoyment; relish; gusto.
examples: Almighty Vanity! to thee they owezest of pleasure, and their balm of woe.
Liberality of disposition and conduct gives the highest zest and relish to social intercourse.

definitions.text: The woody, thick skin inclosing the kernel of a walnut.
To cut into thin slips, as the peel of an orange, lemon, etc.; to squeeze, as peel, over the surface of anything.
To give a relish or flavor to; to heighten the taste or relish of; as, to zest wine.
Marked by spirited enjoyment.
Having a pleasantly stimulating flavor.  Opposite of bland.
marked by spirited enjoyment.
A Greek letter [z.
Seeking; proceeding by inquiry.

pos.cs: Zetetic method (Math.), the method used for finding the value of unknown quantities by direct search, in investigation, or in the solution of problems. [R.] Hutton.

definitions.text: A seeker; -- a name adopted by some of the Pyrrhonists.
A branch of algebra which relates to the direct search for unknown quantities.

pos.etymology: [Gr.  (Paleon.) A genus of extinct Eocene whales, remains of which have been found in the Gulf States. The species had very long and slender bodies and broad serrated teeth.  See Phocodontia.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A genus of extinct Eocene whales, remains of which have been found in the Gulf States. The species had very long and slender bodies and broad serrated teeth.  See Phocodontia.
Any species of Zeuglodonta.
Same as Phocodontia.

A figure by which an adjective or verb, which agrees with a nearer word, is, by way of supplement, referred also to another more remote; as, arma, hic currus fuit;fuit, which agrees directly with currus, is referred also to arma.

pos.etymology: [NL., fr. Gr.  (Zool.) Same as Zygobranchia.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Of or pertaining to zeugma; characterized by zeugma.

pos.etymology: [NL., fr. Gr.  (Zool.) Same as Zygobranchia.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Same as Zygobranchia.
The chief deity of the Greeks, and ruler of the upper world (cf. Hades). He was identified with Jupiter.
Any one of a group of bombycid moths of which the genus Zeuzera is the type. Some of these moths are of large size. The goat moth is an example.
See Ceylanite.

A carnivorous mammal (Viverra zibetha) closely allied to the civet, from which it differs in having the spots on the body less distinct, the throat whiter, and the black rings on the tail more numerous.
Curd produced from milk by adding acetic acid, after rennet has ceased to cause coagulation.
A mineral wax, vert similar to ozocerite. It is found at Zietrisika, Moldavia, whence its name.
The second month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year, corresponding to our May.

pos.etymology: [F. zigzag, G. zickzack, from zacke, zacken, a dentil, tooth.  Cf. Tack a small nail.]

definitions.text: Same as Sicker.

pos.etymology: [F. zigzag, G. zickzack, from zacke, zacken, a dentil, tooth.  Cf. Tack a small nail.]

definitions.text: A temple tower of the Babylonians or Assyrians, consisting of a lofty pyramidal structure, built in successive stages, with outside staircases, and a shrine at the top; -- called also zikkurat.

pos.etymology: [F. zigzag, G. zickzack, from zacke, zacken, a dentil, tooth.  Cf. Tack a small nail.]

definitions.text: Something that has short turns or angles.
examples: The fanatics going straight forward and openly, the politicians by the surer mode of zigzag.

definitions.text: A molding running in a zigzag line; a chevron, or series of chevrons.  See Illust. of Chevron, 3.
See Boyau.
Having short, sharp turns; running this way and that in an onward course.
To form with short turns.
To move in a zigzag manner; also, to have a zigzag shape.
The quality or state of being zigzag; crookedness.
examples: The . . . zigzaggery of my father's approaches.

definitions.text: Having sharp turns.
A temple tower of the Babylonians or Assyrians, consisting of a lofty pyramidal structure, built in successive stages, with outside staircases, and a shrine at the top; -- called also ziggurat.
A low, thorny, suffrutescent, crucifeous plant (Zilla myagroides) found in the deserts of Egypt. Its leaves are boiled in water, and eaten, by the Arabs.
A district or local division, as of a province.
A large, venomous, two-winged fly, native of Abyssinia. It is allied to the tsetse fly, and, like the latter, is destructive to cattle.
A kind of water found in copper mines; water impregnated with copper.

pos.etymology: [G. zink, probably akin to zinn tin: cf. F. zinc, from the German.  Cf. Tin.]

definitions.text: A sponge (Euspongia zimocca) of flat form and fine quality, from the Adriatic, about the Greek islands, and the coast of Barbary.

pos.etymology: [G. zink, probably akin to zinn tin: cf. F. zinc, from the German.  Cf. Tin.]

definitions.text: An abundant element of the magnesium-cadmium group, extracted principally from the minerals zinc blende, smithsonite, calamine, and franklinite, as an easily fusible bluish white metal, which is malleable, especially when heated. It is not easily oxidized in moist air, and hence is used for sheeting, coating galvanized iron, etc. It is used in making brass, britannia, and other alloys, and is also largely consumed in electric batteries. Symbol Zn. Atomic number 30. Atomic weight 65.38.

pos.cs: Butter of zinc (Old Chem.), zinc chloride, ZnCl2, a deliquescent white waxy or oily substance. -- Oxide of zinc. (Chem.) See Zinc oxide, below. -- Zinc amine (Chem.), a white amorphous substance, Zn(NH2)2, obtained by the action of ammonia on zinc ethyl; -- called also zinc amide. -- Zinc amyle (Chem.), a colorless, transparent liquid, composed of zinc and amyle, which, when exposed to the atmosphere, emits fumes, and absorbs oxygen with rapidity. -- Zinc blende [cf. G. zinkblende] (Min.), a native zinc sulphide.  See Blende, n. (a). -- Zinc bloom [cf. G. zinkblumen flowers of zinc, oxide of zinc] (Min.), hydrous carbonate of zinc, usually occurring in white earthy incrustations; -- called also hydrozincite. -- Zinc ethyl (Chem.), a colorless, transparent, poisonous liquid, composed of zinc and ethyl, which takes fire spontaneously on exposure to the atmosphere. -- Zinc green, a green pigment consisting of zinc and cobalt oxides; -- called also Rinmann's green. -- Zinc methyl (Chem.), a colorless mobile liquid Zn(CH3)2, produced by the action of methyl iodide on a zinc sodium alloy.  It has a disagreeable odor, and is spontaneously inflammable in the air. It has been of great importance in the synthesis of organic compounds, and is the type of a large series of similar compounds, as zinc ethyl, zinc amyle, etc. -- Zinc oxide (Chem.), the oxide of zinc, ZnO, forming a light fluffy sublimate when zinc is burned; -- called also flowers of zinc, philosopher's wool, nihil album, etc. The impure oxide produced by burning the metal, roasting its ores, or in melting brass, is called also pompholyx, and tutty. -- Zinc spinel (Min.), a mineral, related to spinel, consisting essentially of the oxides of zinc and aluminium; gahnite. -- Zinc vitriol (Chem.), zinc sulphate.  See White vitriol, under Vitriol. -- Zinc white, a white powder consisting of zinc oxide, used as a pigment.

definitions.text: To coat with zinc; to galvanize.
Zinc chloride.
Pertaining to, containing, or resembling, zinc; zincous.
A binary compound of zinc.
Containing or affording zinc.
The act or process of applying zinc; the condition of being zincified, or covered with zinc; galvanization.
To coat or impregnate with zinc.
Native zinc oxide; a brittle, translucent mineral, of an orange-red color; -- called also red zinc ore, and red oxide of zinc.
The act or process of applying zinc; galvanization.
Pertaining to zinc, or having its appearance.
A combining form from zinc; in chemistry, designating zinc as an element of certain double compounds. Also used adjectively.
The positive electrode of an electrolytic cell; anode.
A zinc plate prepared for printing by zincography; also, a print from such a plate.
An engraver on zinc.
Of or pertaining to zincography; as, zincographic processes.
The art or process of engraving or etching on zinc, in which the design is left in relief in the style of a wood cut, the rest of the ground being eaten away by acid.
Pertaining to, or resembling, zinc; -- said of the electricity of the zincous plate in connection with a copper plate in a voltaic circle; also, designating the positive pole.
Electrically polarized like the surface of the zinc presented to the acid in a battery, which has zincous affinity.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, zinc; zincic; as, zincous salts.
Of or pertaining to the positive pole of a galvanic battery; electro-positive.

A publication similar to a magazine{4} but in electronic rather than printed form, maintained as data files on a computer and accessible via the world wide web; sometimes called e-zine (electronic, as in e-mail.
A gypsy.
A small, edible, freshwater European perch (Aspro zingel), having a round, elongated body and prominent snout.
Of or pertaining to ginger, or to a tribe (Zingibereae) of endogenous plants of the order Scitamineae.  See Scitamineous.

pos.etymology: [From Zinken, director at one time of the Hanoverian mines.]

definitions.text: See Zinc.

pos.etymology: [From Zinken, director at one time of the Hanoverian mines.]

definitions.text: A steel-gray metallic mineral, a sulphide of antimony and lead.

pos.etymology: [NL. So called after Professor Zinn, of G (Bot.) Any plant of the composite genus Zinnia, Mexican herbs with opposite leaves and large gay-colored blossoms. Zinnia elegans is the commonest species in cultivation.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: See Zincky.

pos.etymology: [NL. So called after Professor Zinn, of G (Bot.) Any plant of the composite genus Zinnia, Mexican herbs with opposite leaves and large gay-colored blossoms. Zinnia elegans is the commonest species in cultivation.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Any plant of the composite genus Zinnia, Mexican herbs with opposite leaves and large gay-colored blossoms. Zinnia elegans is the commonest species in cultivation.

pos.etymology: [So called after Zinnwald, in Bohemia, where it occurs.]

definitions.text: A kind of mica containing lithium, often associated with tin ore.
The delundung.
Same as Zingiberaceous.
A hill in Jerusalem, which, after the capture of that city by the Israelites, became the royal residence of David and his successors.
Hence, the theocracy, or church of God.
The heavenly Jerusalem; heaven.

Among the Jews, a theory, plan, or movement for colonizing their own race in Palestine, the land of Zion, or, if that is impracticable, elsewhere, either for religious or nationalizing purposes; -- called also Zion movement.
A hissing or sibilant sound such as that made by a flying bullet.
a quantity of no importance.
a device for locking together two toothed edges by means of a sliding tab.
To make, or move with, a sound like a zip{1}.
a device for locking together two toothed edges by means of a sliding tab.
a full nine-digit zip code.  See zip code.

Any one of a set of numbers assigned by the United States Postal Service to designate a particular postal delivery area.  One or more zip codes are assigned to each post office.  The numbers initially had five digits (the initial code), indicating state and post office.  Later, four more optional digits were added (the expanded code) indicating the box number or delivery route.  The full set of nine digits is also referred to as zip + 4.  The code is appended in an address to the line bearing the city and state names, as in  [Also spelled ZIP code and Zip code.]PJC]

pos.etymology: [F., the same word as jargon.  See Jargon a variety of zircon.]

definitions.text: to affix a zip code to (an address or a letter).

pos.etymology: [F., the same word as jargon.  See Jargon a variety of zircon.]

definitions.text: A natural family of cetaceans comprising the beaked whales; in some esp. former classifications included in the family Physeteridae.

pos.etymology: [F., the same word as jargon.  See Jargon a variety of zircon.]

definitions.text: See Xiphioid.

pos.etymology: [F., the same word as jargon.  See Jargon a variety of zircon.]

definitions.text: a device for locking together two toothed edges by means of a sliding tab.

pos.etymology: [F., the same word as jargon.  See Jargon a variety of zircon.]

definitions.text: quick and energetic.
full of life and energy.

pos.etymology: [F., the same word as jargon.  See Jargon a variety of zircon.]

definitions.text: The consort of Marduk.

pos.etymology: [F., the same word as jargon.  See Jargon a variety of zircon.]

definitions.text: A combining form (also used adjectively) designating zirconium as an element of certain double compounds; zircono-; as in zircofluoric acid, sodium zircofluoride.

pos.etymology: [F., the same word as jargon.  See Jargon a variety of zircon.]

definitions.text: A double fluoride of zirconium and hydrogen, or some other positive element or radical; as, zircofluoride of sodium.

pos.etymology: [F., the same word as jargon.  See Jargon a variety of zircon.]

definitions.text: A mineral consisting predominantly of zirconium silicate (Zr2SiO4) occurring in tetragonal crystals, usually of a brown or gray color. It consists of silica and zirconia.  A red variety, used as a gem, is called hyacinth. Colorless, pale-yellow or smoky-brown varieties from Ceylon are called jargon.
an imitation gemstone made of cubic zirconia.

pos.cs: Zircon syenite, a coarse-grained syenite containing zircon crystals and often also elaeolite. It is largely developed in Southern Norway.

definitions.text: Zirconia.
A salt of zirconic acid.

The oxide of zirconium (ZrO2), obtained as a white powder, and possessing both acid and basic properties.  On account of its infusibility, and brilliant luminosity when incandescent, it is used as an ingredient of sticks for the Drummomd light.

pos.cs: cubic zirconia.  A colorless form of zirconia similar in appearance and refractivity to diamond, and used as a substitute for diamonds in inexpensive jewelry; -- also known by the acronym CZ.

definitions.text: Pertaining to, containing, or resembling, zirconium; as, zirconic oxide; zirconic compounds.

pos.cs: Zirconic acid, an acid of zirconium analogous to carbonic and silicic acids, known only in its salts.

definitions.text: A rare element of the carbon-silicon group, intermediate between the metals and nonmetals, obtained from the mineral zircon as a dark sooty powder, or as a gray metallic crystalline substance. Symbol Zr. Atomic weight, 90.4.
A light, similar to the calcium light, produced by incandescent zirconia.
See Zirco-.
A double eight-sided pyramid, a form common with tetragonal crystals; -- so called because this form often occurs in crystals of zircon.
a pimple.

An instrument of music used in Austria and Germany. It has from thirty to forty wires strung across a shallow sounding-board, which lies horizontally on a table before the performer, who uses both hands in playing on it. [Not to be confounded with the old lute-shaped cittern, or cithern.]

pos.etymology: [NL., from L. zizanium darnel, cockle, Gr.  (Bot.) A genus of grasses including Indian rice.  See Indian rice, under Rice.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A tubular pasta in short pieces.

pos.etymology: [NL., from L. zizanium darnel, cockle, Gr.  (Bot.) A genus of grasses including Indian rice.  See Indian rice, under Rice.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: See Cittern.

pos.etymology: [NL., from L. zizanium darnel, cockle, Gr.  (Bot.) A genus of grasses including Indian rice.  See Indian rice, under Rice.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A genus of grasses including Indian rice.  See Indian rice, under Rice.
The suslik.

The tassels of twisted cords or threads on the corners of the upper garment worn by strict Jews. The Hebrew for this word is translated in both the Authorized and Revised Versions (Deut. xxii. 12) by the word Webster 1913 Suppl.]

pos.etymology: [NL., from Gr. zw^,on an animal +  (Zool.) A suborder of Actinaria, including Zoanthus and allied genera, which are permanently attached by their bases.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A suborder of Actinaria, including Zoanthus and allied genera, which are permanently attached by their bases.
Same as Anthozoa.
Of or pertaining to the Zoantharia.
The zooids of a compound anthozoan, collectively.
Of or pertaining to the Zoanthacea.

pos.etymology: [Gr.  (Med.) A kind of monomania in which the patient believes himself transformed into one of the lower animals.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A kind of monomania in which the patient believes himself transformed into one of the lower animals.

A genus of Actinaria, including numerous species, found mostly in tropical seas. The zooids or polyps resemble small, elongated actinias united together at their bases by fleshy stolons, and thus forming extensive groups. The tentacles are small and bright colored.
A kind of domestic cattle reared in Asia for its flesh and milk. It is supposed to be a hybrid between the zebu and the yak.

pos.etymology: [It. fr. L. socculus.  See Socle, and cf. Zacco.]

definitions.text: Same as Socle.
Same as Socle.
a trade name for simvastatin.

pos.etymology: [F. zodiaque (cf. It. zodiaco), fr. L. zodiacus, Gr. zw^,on an animal, akin to 1913 Webster]

definitions.text: An imaginary belt in the heavens, 16 (b) A figure representing the signs, symbols, and constellations of the zodiac.1913 Webster]
A girdle; a belt.
examples: By his side,zodiac, hung the sword.

definitions.text: Of or pertaining to the zodiac; situated within the zodiac; as, the zodiacal planets.

pos.cs: Zodiacal light, a luminous tract of the sky, of an elongated, triangular figure, lying near the ecliptic, its base being on the horizon, and its apex at varying altitudes. It is to be seen only in the evening, after twilight, and in the morning before dawn. It is supposed to be due to sunlight reflected from multitudes of meteoroids revolving about the sun nearly in the plane of the ecliptic.

pos.etymology: [NL., fr. Gr.  (Zool.) A peculiar larval stage of certain decapod Crustacea, especially of crabs and certain Anomura. [Written also zoaea.]1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A peculiar larval stage of certain decapod Crustacea, especially of crabs and certain Anomura.

pos.etymology: [Gr.  An optical toy, in which figures made to revolve on the inside of a cylinder, and viewed through slits in its circumference, appear like a single figure passing through a series of natural motions as if animated or mechanically moved.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: An optical toy, in which figures made to revolve on the inside of a cylinder, and viewed through slits in its circumference, appear like a single figure passing through a series of natural motions as if animated or mechanically moved.
A Jewish cabalistic book attributed by tradition to Rabbi Simon ben Yochi, who lived about the end of the 1st century, a. d.  Modern critics believe it to be a compilation of the 13th century.

pos.etymology: [Gr.  (Zool.) Of or pertaining to animals, or animal life.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Of or pertaining to animals, or animal life.

pos.etymology: [After its discoverer, Von Zois, an Austrian mineralogist.]

definitions.text: See Meride.

pos.etymology: [After its discoverer, Von Zois, an Austrian mineralogist.]

definitions.text: Having the characteristic of Zoilus, a bitter, envious, unjust critic, who lived about 270 years before Christ.

pos.etymology: [After its discoverer, Von Zois, an Austrian mineralogist.]

definitions.text: Resemblance to Zoilus in style or manner; carping criticism; detraction.
examples: Bring candid eyes the perusal of men's works, and let not Zoilism or detraction blast well-intended labors.

pos.etymology: [After its discoverer, Von Zois, an Austrian mineralogist.]

definitions.text: A grayish or whitish mineral occurring in orthorhombic, prismatic crystals, also in columnar masses. It is a silicate of alumina and lime, and is allied to epidote.
Reverence for animal life or belief in animal powers and influences, as among savages.
A doctrine, now discarded, that the phenomena of life are due to a peculiar vital principle; the theory of vital force.

pos.etymology: [So called after Friedrich Z, a German physicist.]

definitions.text: An Asiatic burrowing rodent (Siphneus aspalax) resembling the mole rat. It is native of the Altai Mountains.

pos.etymology: [So called after Friedrich Z, a German physicist.]

definitions.text: In the style of Zola (see Zolaism).

pos.etymology: [So called after Friedrich Z, a German physicist.]

definitions.text: The literary theories and practices of the French novelist Emile Zola (1840-1902); naturalism, esp. in a derogatory sense.

pos.etymology: [So called after Friedrich Z, a German physicist.]

definitions.text: Parallel lines that are made to appear convergent or divergent by means of oblique intersections.

Literally, a customs union; specifically, applied to the several customs unions successively formed under the leadership of Prussia among certain German states for establishing liberty of commerce among themselves and common tariff on imports, exports, and transit.
See Zumbooruk.
A zone or band; a layer.

pos.cs: Zona pellucida. [NL.] (Biol.) (a) The outer transparent layer, or envelope, of the ovum. It is a more or less elastic membrane with radiating striae, and corresponds to the cell wall of an ordinary cell.  See Ovum, and Illust. of Microscope. (b) The zona radiata. -- Zona radiata [NL.] (Biol.), a radiately striated membrane situated next the yolk of an ovum, or separated from it by a very delicate membrane only.

definitions.text: Of or pertaining to a zone; having the form of a zone or zones.

pos.cs: Zonal equation (Crystallog.), the mathematical relation which belongs to all the planes of a zone, and expresses their common position with reference to the axes. -- Zonal structure (Crystallog.), a structure characterized by the arrangements of color, inclusions, etc., of a crystal in parallel or concentric layers, which usually follow the outline of the crystal, and mark the changes that have taken place during its growth. -- Zonal symmetry. (Biol.) See the Note under Symmetry.

definitions.text: A belt or girdle which the Christians and Jews of the Levant were obliged to wear to distinguish them from Mohammedans.
A division of Mammalia in which the placenta is zonelike.

pos.etymology: [F. zone, L. zona, Gr. zw`nh; akin to zwnny`nai to gird, Lith. j a girdle, j to gird, Zend y.]

definitions.text: Divided by parallel planes; as, zonate tetraspores, found in certain red algae.

pos.etymology: [F. zone, L. zona, Gr. zw`nh; akin to zwnny`nai to gird, Lith. j a girdle, j to gird, Zend y.]

definitions.text: A girdle; a cincture.
examples: An embroidered zone surrounds her waist.
Loose were her tresses seen, her zone unbound.

definitions.text: One of the five great divisions of the earth, with respect to latitude and temperature.
examples: Commerce . . . defies every wind, outrides every tempest, and invades.

definitions.text: The portion of the surface of a sphere included between two parallel planes; the portion of a surface of revolution included between two planes perpendicular to the axis.
A band or stripe extending around a body.
A series of planes having mutually parallel intersections.
Circuit; circumference.
An area or part of a region characterized by uniform or similar animal and plant life; a life zone; as, Littoral zone, Austral zone, etc.
A series of faces whose intersection lines with each other are parallel.
The aggregate of stations, in whatsoever direction or on whatsoever line of railroad, situated between certain maximum and minimum limits from a point at which a shipment of traffic originates.
any area to or within which a shipment or transportation cost is constant;

pos.cs: Abyssal zone. (Phys. Geog.) See under Abyssal. -- Zone axis (Crystallog.), a straight line passing through the center of a crystal, to which all the planes of a given zone are parallel.

pos.etymology: [Zone + Gr.  (Zool.) Any one of several of South African lizards of the genus Zonura, common in rocky situations.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: To girdle; to encircle.

pos.etymology: [Zone + Gr.  (Zool.) Any one of several of South African lizards of the genus Zonura, common in rocky situations.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Wearing a zone, or girdle.
Having zones, or concentric bands; striped.
Zonate.

pos.etymology: [Zone + Gr.  (Zool.) Any one of several of South African lizards of the genus Zonura, common in rocky situations.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Not having a zone; ungirded.
examples: The reeling goddess with the zoneless waist.
In careless folds, loose fell her zoneless vest.

pos.etymology: [Zone + Gr.  (Zool.) Any one of several of South African lizards of the genus Zonura, common in rocky situations.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: See Zonar.

pos.etymology: [Zone + Gr.  (Zool.) Any one of several of South African lizards of the genus Zonura, common in rocky situations.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Of or pertaining to a zone; zone-shaped.

pos.etymology: [Zone + Gr.  (Zool.) Any one of several of South African lizards of the genus Zonura, common in rocky situations.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A little zone, or girdle.

pos.etymology: [Zone + Gr.  (Zool.) Any one of several of South African lizards of the genus Zonura, common in rocky situations.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A zonule.

pos.etymology: [Zone + Gr.  (Zool.) Any one of several of South African lizards of the genus Zonura, common in rocky situations.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Any one of several of South African lizards of the genus Zonura, common in rocky situations.
A combining form from Gr. zww^,n an animal, as in zoogenic, zoology, etc.
Pertaining to zoochemistry.
Animal chemistry; particularly, the description of the chemical compounds entering into the composition of the animal body, in distinction from biochemistry.

pos.etymology: [Zoo- + Gr.  Animal chemistry; zoochemistry. Dunglison.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Animal chemistry; zoochemistry.

pos.etymology: [NL., dim. from Gr. zw^,on an animal +  (Zool.) One of the small green granulelike bodies found in the interior of certain stentors, hydras, and other invertebrates.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: One of the small green granulelike bodies found in the interior of certain stentors, hydras, and other invertebrates.
A cyst formed by certain Protozoa and unicellular plants which the contents divide into a large number of granules, each of which becomes a germ.

pos.etymology: [NL., fr. Gr. zw^,on an animal +  (Zool.) The common support, often branched, of certain species of social Infusoria.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: The common support, often branched, of certain species of social Infusoria.

pos.etymology: [NL., fr. Gr. zw^,on an animal +  (Zool.) The branched, and often treelike, support of the colonies of certain Infusoria.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: The branched, and often treelike, support of the colonies of certain Infusoria.

pos.etymology: [NL., fr. Gr. zw^,on an animal +  (Zool.) One of the cells or tubes which inclose the feeling zooids of Bryozoa.  See Illust. of Sea Moss.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: One of the cells or tubes which inclose the feeling zooids of Bryozoa.  See Illust. of Sea Moss.

pos.etymology: [Zoo- + Gr.  (Zool.) A peculiar organic red coloring matter found in the feathers of various birds.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A peculiar organic red coloring matter found in the feathers of various birds.

pos.etymology: [Zoo- + Gr.  (Biol.) Of or pertaining zoogamy.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Of or pertaining zoogamy.

pos.etymology: [Zoo- + -gen + -ic: cf. Gr.  (Biol.) Of or pertaining to zoogeny, animal production.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: The sexual reproduction of animals.

pos.etymology: [Zoo- + -gen + -ic: cf. Gr.  (Biol.) Of or pertaining to zoogeny, animal production.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Of or pertaining to zoogeny, animal production.

pos.etymology: [Zoo- + root of Gr.  The doctrine of the formation of living beings.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: The doctrine of the formation of living beings.
Of or pertaining to zoography.
The study or description of the geographical distribution of animals.

pos.etymology: [NL., from Gr. zw^,on an animal +  (Biol.) A colony or mass of bacteria imbedded in a viscous gelatinous substance. The zoogloea is characteristic of a transitory stage through which rapidly multiplying bacteria pass in the course of their evolution. Also used adjectively.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A colony or mass of bacteria imbedded in a viscous gelatinous substance. The zoogloea is characteristic of a transitory stage through which rapidly multiplying bacteria pass in the course of their evolution. Also used adjectively.
One who describes animals, their forms and habits.
Of or pertaining to the description of animals.
A zoographer.
A description of animals, their forms and habits.
Pertaining to, or resembling, an animal.

pos.etymology: [Zoo- + Gr.  The worship of animals.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: An organic body or cell having locomotion, as a spermatic cell or spermatozooid.
An animal in one of its inferior stages of development, as one of the intermediate forms in alternate generation.

pos.etymology: [Zoo- + Gr.  The worship of animals.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Of or pertaining to a zooid; as, a zooidal form.

pos.etymology: [Zoo- + Gr.  The worship of animals.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: The worship of animals.
A Zoologist.
Of or pertaining to Zoology, or the science of animals.
In a Zoological manner; according to the principles of Zoology.
One who is well versed in Zoology.
To study Zoology; esp., to collect animals for study.
That part of biology which relates to the animal kingdom, including the structure, embryology, evolution, classification, habits, and distribution of all animals, both living and extinct.
A treatise on this science.
A pigment giving the black color to the feathers of many birds.

pos.etymology: [Zoo- + Gr.  Of or pertaining to zoomorphism.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Of or pertaining to zoomorphism.
The transformation of men into beasts.
The quality of representing or using animal forms; as, zoomorphism in ornament.
The representation of God, or of gods, in the form, or with the attributes, of the lower animals.
examples: To avoid the error of anthropomorphism, we fall into the vastly greater, and more absurd, error of zoomorphism.

definitions.text: An animal which is the sole product of a single egg; -- opposed to zooid.

pos.etymology: [Gr. zw^,on an animal: cf.  F. zoonique.]

definitions.text: Of or pertaining to animals; obtained from animal substances.
One of the segments of the body of an articulate animal.
The laws of animal life, or the science which treats of the phenomena of animal life, their causes and relations.
Same as Zoonite.
Animal pathology.

pos.etymology: [NL., fr. Gr.  (Zool.) An artificial group comprising various carnivorous and insectivorous animals.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: An artificial group comprising various carnivorous and insectivorous animals.

pos.etymology: [Gr. zw^,on an animal +  Feeding on animals.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A animal that feeds on animal food.

pos.etymology: [Gr. zw^,on an animal +  Feeding on animals.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Feeding on animals.

pos.etymology: [Zoo- + Gr.  A lover of animals. Southey.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A lover of animals.

pos.etymology: [Gr. zw^,on an animal + fe`rein to bear; cf. F. zoophorique.]

definitions.text: Love of animals.

pos.etymology: [Gr. zw^,on an animal + fe`rein to bear; cf. F. zoophorique.]

definitions.text: A zoophyte.

pos.etymology: [Gr. zw^,on an animal + fe`rein to bear; cf. F. zoophorique.]

definitions.text: Bearing or supporting the figure of an animal; as, a zoophoric column.
The part between the architrave and cornice; the frieze; -- so called from the figures of animals carved upon it.

pos.etymology: [NL., from Gr. zw^,on an animal + fyto`n a plant.]

definitions.text: An extensive artificial and heterogeneous group of animals, formerly adopted by many Zoologists. It included the c1913 Webster]

pos.etymology: [F. zoophyte, Gr. zw^,on an animal + Zodiac, and Be, v. i.]

definitions.text: Any one of numerous species of invertebrate animals which more or less resemble plants in appearance, or mode of growth, as the corals, gorgonians, sea anemones, hydroids, bryozoans, sponges, etc., especially any of those that form compound colonies having a branched or treelike form, as many corals and hydroids.
Of or pertaining to zoophytes.
Pertaining to, or resembling, a zoophyte.
Of or pertaining to zoophytology; as, zoophytological observations.
The natural history zoophytes.
An instrument similar to, or the same as, the, the phenakistoscope, by means of which pictures projected upon a screen are made to exhibit the natural movements of animals, and the like.
Animal psychology.
One of the spermatic particles; spermatozoid.
A spore, or conceptacle containing zoospores.

A spore provided with one or more slender cilia, by the vibration of which it swims in the water. Zoospores are produced by many green, and by some olive-brown, algae. In certain species they are divided into the larger macrozoospores and the smaller microzoospores. Called also sporozoid, and swarmspore.
See Swarmspore.
Of or pertaining to zoospores; of the nature of zoospores.
Containing the remains of organized bodies; -- said of rock or soil.
Of or pertaining to zootomy.
One who dissects animals, or is skilled in zootomy.
The dissection or the anatomy of animals; -- distinguished from androtomy.
Of or pertaining to the nourishment of animals.
The wood pigeon.
A European fresh-water bream (Abramis ballerus).
The urubu, or American black vulture.

pos.etymology: [Sp. zorilla, zorillo, dim. of zorra, zorro, a fox: cf. F. zorille.]

definitions.text: Same as Zorilla.

pos.etymology: [Sp. zorilla, zorillo, dim. of zorra, zorro, a fox: cf. F. zorille.]

definitions.text: Either one of two species of small African carnivores of the genus Ictonyx allied to the weasels and skunks.
The persian prophet Zarathustra, who probably lived in the second millenium B. C.  His treachings form the basis for the religion Zoroastrianism.
Of or pertaining to Zoroaster, or his religious system.
A follower of Zoroaster; one who accepts Zoroastrianism.

The religious system of Zoroaster, the legislator and prophet of the ancient Persians, which was the national faith of Persia; mazdeism. The system presupposes a good spirit (Ormuzd) and an opposing evil spirit (Ahriman).  Cf. Fire worship, under Fire, and Parsee.
Same as Zoroastrianism.
Shingles.
A genus of plants of the Naiadaceae, or Pondweed family. Zostera marina is commonly known as sea wrack, and eelgrass.

pos.etymology: [NL., fr. Gr.  (Zool.) A genus of birds that comprises the white-eyes.  See White-eye.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A genus of birds that comprises the white-eyes.  See White-eye.

pos.etymology: [F., fr. Ar. Zouaoua a tribe of Kabyles living among the Jurjura mountains in Algeria.]

definitions.text: One of an active and hardy body of soldiers in the French service, originally Arabs, but now composed of Frenchmen who wear the Arab dress.
An exclamation formerly used as an oath, and an expression of anger or wonder.
To stew, as flounders, eels, etc., with just enough or liquid to cover them.
The aurochs.
A stump of a tree.
A skullcap covering the tonsure, worn under the berretta. The pope's is white; a cardinal's red; a bishop's purple; a priest's black.
A little flute or flageolet, especially that which is used to teach birds.
The American widgeon.
Any member of the tribe of Zulus; a Zulu-Kaffir. See Zulus.

One of the most important members of the South African, or Bantu, family of languages, spoken partly in Natal and partly in Zululand, but understood, and more or less in use, over a wide territory, at least as far north as the Zambezi; -- called also Zulu-Kaffir.
A word used in spoken communications to represent the letter Z.

pos.etymology: [Turk. & Ar. zamb, fr. Ar. zamb a hornet.]

definitions.text: A member of the Bantu race comprising the Zulus and the Kaffirs.

pos.etymology: [Turk. & Ar. zamb, fr. Ar. zamb a hornet.]

definitions.text: The most important tribe belonging to the Kaffir race.  They inhabit a region on the southeast coast of Africa, but formerly occupied a much more extensive country.  They are noted for their warlike disposition, courage, and military skill.

pos.etymology: [Turk. & Ar. zamb, fr. Ar. zamb a hornet.]

definitions.text: A small cannon supported by a swiveled rest on the back of a camel, whence it is fired, -- used in the East.
See Zymic, Zymological, etc.
A tribe of Pueblo Indians occupying a village in New Mexico, on the Zu River.
Of or pertaining to the Zu -- n. A ZuWebster 1913 Suppl.]
A fluosilicate of alumina occurring in tetrahedral crystals at the Zu mine in Colorado.
An Austrian silver coin equivalent to 20 kreutzers, or about 10 cents.

pos.etymology: [G., fr. zwie- two, twice (see Twice) + backen to bake.]

definitions.text: A kind of biscuit or rusk first baked in a loaf and afterwards cut and toasted.

Of or pertaining to Ulric Zwingli (1481-1531), the reformer of German Switzerland, who maintained that in the Lord's Supper the true body of Christ is present by the contemplation of faith but not in essence or reality, and that the sacrament is a memorial without mystical elements.
See under Zygosphene.
One of the articular processes of a vertebra, of which there are usually four, two anterior and two posterior.  See under Vertebra.

pos.etymology: [Cf. Gr.  (Zool.) Any one of numerous species of moths of the family Zygaenidae, most of which are bright colored. The wood nymph and the vine forester are examples. Also used adjectively.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Any one of numerous species of moths of the family Zygaenidae, most of which are bright colored. The wood nymph and the vine forester are examples. Also used adjectively.

pos.etymology: [NL., from Gr. zygo`n a yoke +  (Zool.) A division of marine gastropods in which the gills are developed on both sides of the body and the renal organs are also paired. The abalone (Haliotis) and the keyhole limpet (Fissurella) are examples.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A division of marine gastropods in which the gills are developed on both sides of the body and the renal organs are also paired. The abalone (Haliotis) and the keyhole limpet (Fissurella) are examples.
Of or pertaining to the Zygobranchia.
Any zygodactylous bird.
The zygodactylous birds. In a restricted sense applied to a division of birds which includes the barbets, toucans, honey guides, and other related birds.
Same as Scansores.
Yoke-footed; having the toes disposed in pairs; -- applied to birds which have two toes before and two behind, as the parrot, cuckoo, woodpecker, etc.
The jugal, malar, or cheek bone.
Of, pertaining to, or in the region of, the zygoma.

pos.cs: Zygomatic arch, the arch of bone beneath the orbit, formed in most mammals by the union of the malar, or jugal, with the zygomatic process of the temporal bone. In the lower vertebrates other bones may help to form it, and there may be two arches on each side of the skull, as in some reptiles. -- Zygomatic process, a process of the temporal or squamosal bone helping to form the zygomatic arch.

pos.etymology: [Gr. zygo`n a yoke +  (Biol.) Symmetrical bilaterally; -- said of organisms, or parts of organisms, capable of division into two symmetrical halves only in a single plane.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: Symmetrical bilaterally; -- said of organisms, or parts of organisms, capable of division into two symmetrical halves only in a single plane.

pos.etymology: [Gr. zygo`n a yoke + fyto`n a plant.]

definitions.text: A natural family of small trees, shrubs, and herbs of warm arid and saline regions; it is often resinous, and some are poisonous.  It contains the genera Zygophyllum; Tribulus; Guaiacum; and Larrea.

pos.etymology: [Gr. zygo`n a yoke + fyto`n a plant.]

definitions.text: A genus of usually tropical herbs or shrubs having ill-smelling foliage and flower buds that are used as capers: bean capers.

pos.etymology: [Gr. zygo`n a yoke + fyto`n a plant.]

definitions.text: Any plant of a proposed class or grand division (Zygophytes, Zygophyta, or Zygosporeae), in which reproduction consists in the union of two similar cells.  Cf. Oophyte.
A suborder consisting of the damselflies.
The process of the merging of two gametes.  Same as Conjugation.

The property of being either homogeneous or heterogeneous with respect to the allelic genes determining some hereditary trait in a diploid or polyploid organism; if homogeneous, the organism is homozygous; if heterogeneous, it is heterozygous.
A spore formed by the union of the contents of two similar cells, either of the same or of distinct individual plants. Zygosperms are found in certain orders of algae and fungi.

pos.etymology: [Gr. zygo`n a yoke +  (Anat.) A median process on the front part of the neural arch of the vertebrae of most snakes and some lizards, which fits into a fossa, called the zygantrum, on the back part of the arch in front.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: A median process on the front part of the neural arch of the vertebrae of most snakes and some lizards, which fits into a fossa, called the zygantrum, on the back part of the arch in front.
Same as Zygosperm.
The cell resulting from the union of an ovum and a spermatozoon, or (broadly) the developing new organism arising from such a cell.
the second stage of the prophase of meiosis.
of or pertaining to a zygote.
Celluloid.
A soluble ferment, or enzyme.  See Enzyme.
A ferment.
The morbific principle of a zymotic disease.
Pertaining to, or produced by, fermentation; -- formerly, by confusion, used to designate lactic acid.
A mother substance, or antecedent, of an enzyme or chemical ferment; -- applied to such substances as, not being themselves actual ferments, may by internal changes give rise to a ferment.
examples: The pancreas contains but little ready-made ferment, though there is present in it a body, zymogen, which gives birth to the ferment.

pos.etymology: [Zyme + root of Gr.  (Biol.) One of a physiological group of globular bacteria which produces fermentations of diverse nature; -- distinguished from pathogene.1913 Webster]

definitions.text: One of a physiological group of globular bacteria which produces fermentations of diverse nature; -- distinguished from pathogene.
Pertaining to, or formed by, a zymogene.

pos.cs: Zymogenic organism (Biol.), a microorganism, such as the yeast plant of the Bacterium lactis, which sets up certain fermentative processes by which definite chemical products are formed; -- distinguished from a pathogenic organism.  Cf. Micrococcus.

definitions.text: Of or pertaining to zymology.
One who is skilled in zymology, or in the fermentation of liquors.
A treatise on the fermentation of liquors, or the doctrine of fermentation.
The action of enzymes, such as digestion or fermentation; also, the changes produced by such action.
A glutinous substance, insoluble in alcohol, resembling legumin; -- now called vegetable fibrin, vegetable albumin, or gluten casein.

pos.etymology: [Gr. zy`mh ferment, or zy`mwsis fermentation + -meter: cf. F. zymosim.]

definitions.text: An instrument for ascertaining the degree of fermentation occasioned by the mixture of different liquids, and the degree of heat which they acquire in fermentation.
A bacteroid ferment.
An apparatus for determining the fermenting power of yeast by measuring the amount of carbonic acid evolved from a given quantity of sugar.

pos.etymology: [NL., fr. Gr. zymwtiko`s fermentation, fr. zy`mh ferment.]

definitions.text: Invertin.

pos.etymology: [NL., fr. Gr. zymwtiko`s fermentation, fr. zy`mh ferment.]

definitions.text: A fermentation; hence, an analogous process by which an infectious disease is believed to be developed.

pos.etymology: [Gr. zymwtiko`s causing to ferment, fr. zymoy^n to ferment, zy`mh ferment, leaven.]

definitions.text: Of, pertaining to, or caused by, fermentation.
Designating, or pertaining to, a certain class of diseases.  See Zymotic disease, below.

pos.cs: Zymotic disease (Med.),  any epidemic, endemic, contagious, or sporadic affection which is produced by some morbific principle or organism acting on the system like a ferment.

pos.etymology: [Gr. zy^qos a kind of beer + 'e`psein to boil.]

definitions.text: See Zythum.

pos.etymology: [Gr. zy^qos a kind of beer + 'e`psein to boil.]

definitions.text: A brewery.

pos.etymology: [L., fr. Gr. zy^qos a kind of beer; -- so called by the Egyptians.]

definitions.text: A kind of ancient malt beverage; a liquor made from malt and wheat.
